Something I would like to point out about the Square stripe readers is that Square's instructions tell the merchant to make sure that the phone or tablet's volume is turned all the way up so that the device has the greatest sensitivity for capturing the signal through the headphones port. It also states that one should swipe the card SLOWLY. Running the card through the reader as quickly as the guy at the Farmer's Market did would cause the card not to read even when in pristine condition. When one swipes a card, it should take most, if not all, of a second to make just a single pass. Any faster than that and the reader will report a bad read more often than not, especially when swiping back and forth five or six times in a single second as seen in this video.

Both of these issues could have affected the results of this experiment, so I would like to suggest that if Dianna et al. would like to test for more accurate results, take both of these factors into account when repeating the experiment. If the only desire for this experiment was to test whether magnets could affect magnetic stripes on cards, then no need to re-run this experiment since it already proved that point despite the procedural errors.

So fun fact #1. We used to by mag stripe readers all the time from Radio Shack and the like for $15-20. Primarily to use with computer programs to process credit cards back in 2003. The Fun Part. Sometimes it didn't work on the initial install. To Diagnose we swiped them into Notepad. User, the mag swipe readers mount as ... dum dum dum .. keyboards.

Fun fact #2. Some early Samsung smartwatches were equipped with Samsung pay via MST. MST is very much like the credit spoof device used here. The watch is held close to the swipe reader and blasts magnetic pulses that replicate a swipe of the card. There is some suggestion that in Korea Swipe was still King at the time. To be fair, contactless payments in credit cards/smartphones is something that the Japanese and others in the area might be wary of. They've had FeliCa Technology for well over a decade, and there is some suggestion that it is a bit more robust to intrusion than the protocols used for contactless that seem to have become a mainstay in North America.

Using a chip reduces the attack footprint.  That is, the data used by the point of sale, stored by the mechant, the merchant bank, transmitted over the network to the consumer's bank is a single use token.  This effectively eliminates hacks to specific merchants from yielding information that can be used to duplicate credit cards.  That said, the company that stores the information relating the token with specific cards could be hacked, however, that is a single point which is easier to harden than all of the other companies involved (at least in theory).

I've always wondered about the safety in the university physics building that wiped everyone's cards many years ago? They used to say MRIs were 100% safe, now they just say,"mostly safe" and there have been some extremely sketchy incidents and a few deaths from metal flying when the MRI is turned on, metal internally from implants, injuries leaving traces of metals, etc... even a few deaths, BUT that's obvious issues and isn't my long-term concern.
My concern is on a subcellular level... think cancer, damage to cellular structures like Golgi bodies,
Have you ever looked into the effects of strong magnents on blood flow? At what strength does a magnetic field make changes to a human or animal cell? At what strength does it change the RNA replication? Can magnetics change DNA? If so, is the change permanent? Is it reversible?
Time to use something FAR less invasive & less toxic than chemo &/or radiation! Magnetics have an awesome potential to cure, and some potential to cause damage, if used improperly.
Why this hasn't been done is seemingly because it's "too simple" & some data from early on in MRI technology whitewashed the effects, seemingly because of concerns people had about MRI technology.
Someone needs to get working on this. It has quite a few applications and can eliminate the need for some surgeries, and in some cases, to assist in surgery.

Once upon a time I was  computer repair tech. There was a product named Magna-See that we'd use to inspect track alignment/signal-quality on the read/write heads in magnetic tape units.  One would dip a piece of recorded mag tape in the fluid, remove it, and let the solvent evaporate.  You could see the Flux changes on the tape thanks to the incredibly small magnetic particles suspended in the fluid & that adhered to the mag tape. I don't think that product is around any more but there is one named Kyread SDF-130A that looks like an equivalent.  That might be a handy resource for any future experiment where you need to visualize magnetically recorded signals.

Before watching the video I guessed the small magnet and large magnet would have about an equal ability to erase the credit card (the small magnet erased when it was touching, and hence the large magnet also has to be almost touching).

Here's the reason why: simple electric fields from point charges are monopoles that decay as 1/r^2 (inverse square), which many people are familiar of. But there are no magnetic "charges" and the familiar magnetic fields are dipoles: an extra order of "pole," which means they decay as 1/r^3.

The surface of a spherical magnet is distance r from the center, and the volume of a magnet scales as r^3. The total field strength of the magnet also scales as the volume (more aligned spins), so the strength at the surface is surprisingly constant: a larger magnet is r^3 stronger but the surface is further from the center and the field at the surface 1/r^3 weaker.

All magnets of the same material and similar shape basically have the same surface field (to within order of magnetude) and will be equally bad for your credit card.

Since you edit video and like to see magnetic tracks, you might be interested to know that from the invention of video recording in the mid '50s until the early '70's, 2 inch video recordings were physically cut in order to edit. The location for the cut was found using magnetic developer (fine iron oxide particles suspended in a liquid that would evaporate. The exact location was found with a microscope to see the frame start on the control track. Once cut, it was taped together in a way similar to audio tape. It was hard to do well and most shows tried to avoid the need. The most notable exception was "Laugh In" which used extensive physical cutting along with off-line film editing and film style audio post production to create a unique production style.
